results.title: La Bible = the Bible
results.brief_description:
This version of the Bible is illustrated by the mosaics of Monreale, near Palermo (Sicily).

Credits: Producer, Andre Tranche ; director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Marcel Carne, Didier Decoin ; photography, Jean Collomb ; music, Jean-Pierre Benjamin.

results.title: Aloise
results.creator_credit: Alain Dahan and Liliane de Kermadec
results.brief_description:
The painful life of a mentally unstable but highly gifted woman is unveiled in this film, based on episodes from the life of an actual person. Aloise creates a series of haunting drawings while she is incarcerated in an institution for the insane in turn-of-the-century Switzerland. She endures torments as a musically gifted girl and later as a young woman; her developing madness and the barbaric treatments of the time are shown.

Credits: Producer, Alain Dahan ; director, Liliane de Kermadec ; writers, Liliane de Kermadec, Andre Techine ; photography, Jean Penzer.
Cast: Roger Blin, Delphine Seyrig, Jacques Weber, Isabelle Huppert, Julien Guiomar, Michel Lonsdale.

results.title: The Virgin queen
results.creator_credit: Henry Koster, Charles Brackett and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Bette Davis gives her second memorable performance as Queen Elizabeth I in this swashbuckling historical drama that also features Joan Collins in an early screen performance. It is the story of the aging queen’s attraction to handsome Sir Walter Raleigh (Richard Todd) and her bitter clash with a scheming, younger rival (Collins). Rich in historical detail, lavish with authentic cotumes and period decor and enlivened by thrilling swordplay, “The Virgin Queen” is a legendary re-creation of one of England’s most fascinating eras, made all the more alluring by Davis’ dynamic performance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Henry Koster, Charles Brackett and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: Pin up girl
results.creator_credit: Bruce Humberstone, William Le Baron and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Gorgeous Betty Grable (voted the Armed Forces’ favourite pin up girl), stars as a War Department typist, who doubles as a small-time USO entertainer desperate for a chance at the big-time. Her penchant for telling lies gets her into all sorts of trouble especially when she fibs her way into the company of war hero Tommy Dooley (John Harvey) by pretending to be a musical star. Her life gets more complicated when she is appointed secretary to the handsome war hero. Barely disguised, she manages to fool him for a time, but not when she flashes those million dollar legs! Grable turns in a wonderful performance and there are several excellent musical numbers.

results.title: La Triche = the Cheat
results.brief_description:
Michel Verta, a police officer, lives happy in Bordeaux with his wife Nathalie and their child. From time to time he indulges in homosexual encounters. During a routine crime enquiry in a night-club, he meets Bernard, a musician, with whom he falls in love. Michel’s family finds out, and their reactions to the news are quite predictable. When Bernard accidentally kills a man who has been blackmailing him, the gay couple’s troubles are intensified, especially since Michel tries to illegally protect Bernard. The two lovers are caught in an increasing spiral of lies and despair.

Credits: Producer, Denise Petitdidier ; director, Yannick Bellon ; writers, Yannick Bellon, Alain Marcel, Remi Waterhouse ; photography, Houchang Baharlou ; music, Catherine Lara.
Cast: Victor Lanoux, Xavier Deluc, Anny Duperey, Michel Galabru, Valerie Mairesse, Michel Galabru.

results.title: Moon over Miami
results.creator_credit: Walter Lang, Harry Joe Brown and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: When two sisters (played by Betty Grable and Carole Landis) fail to receive an expected inheritance, they decide to pool their resources with their Aunt and head for Florida, posing as an heiress, a secretary and a maid in the hopes of ensnaring a couple of millionaires. Grable is soon involved with two, Don Ameche and Robert Cummings, but all is not what it seems. Ameche is just as broke as the girls, but woos gold-digger Grable with his smooth talk and charming ways, with genuine millionaire Cummings in hot pursuit. A bright and breezy song-filled musical, as Grable turns in some fine dance routines with the Condos Brothers. Fabulous comic performances from the cast help make this film one of the best Hollywood musicals of its era.

results.title: Les Seins de Glace = Icy Breasts
results.creator_credit: Alain Delon, Raymond Danon and Georges Lautner
results.brief_description:
Francois Rollin, a TV writer, meets a lonely woman on the beach and pushes his way into her life. Peggy lives alone in a grand mansion with a groundkeeper cum spy. Rilsen, a lawyer, who is secretely in love with Peggy, is trying his best to push Rollin away from Peggy. But to no avail. The mysteries, the silences and the strange men surrounding Peggy only contribute to tease the TV writer’s curiosity. As Rollin delves further into Peggy’s past, he discovers that she has killed every man who has ever gotten close to her.

Credits: Producers, Raymond Danon, Alain Delon ; director, Georges Lautner ; writer, Georges Lautner ; photography, Maurice Fellous ; music, Philippe Sarde ; second assistant director, Robin Davis.
Cast: Mireille Darc, Alain Delon, Claude Brasseur, Nicoletta Machiavelli, Andre Falcon.

results.title: Les Enfants du Placard = the Closet Children
results.brief_description:
Nicolas bears the psychological scars of unbearable guilt. As a boy, he was given the job of looking after his mentally unstable mother and protecting her from herself. One day, he and his sister went instead into a large closet and marked one another with the blade of their father’s sword cane as a bonding ritual. While they were occupied in this manner, the boy’s mother hung herself and died. Now an adult, he still has an unhealthily strong fixation on his sister. One day, his sister arrives for a visit accompanied by her husband, Berlu. Although the reunion is warm and moving, the relationship with their father remains tense.

Credits: Producer, Michel Chanderli ; director, Benoit Jacquot ; writer, Benoit Jacquot ; photography, Pierre Lhomme ; music, Robert Schumann, I Santo California.
Cast: Brigitte Fossey, Lou Castel, Jean Sorel, Georges Marchal, Isabelle Weingarten, Hassan Fall.

results.title: Angele
results.brief_description:
Seduced and abandoned, Angele, a young naive peasant girl goes to Marseilles where she prostitutes herself in order to support her child. Angele’s father fetches her back to the farm, forcibly locking the girl and her newborn baby in his cellar. In Pagnol’s more Gionoesque works, a major theme is the Land and its relationship to Woman: both can be barren or fertile, unforgiving or kind, depending on circumstance and how one treats them. The earth’s fertility is often symbolised by spring water and traditionally baked bread; their absence indicates a world out of joint. Pagnol liked to celebrate the testing and renewal of human bonds; along with Jacques Feyder but in an entirely different, affirmative register, he is one of the French cinema’s great observer of the family.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992. ‘Angele’ was the first French film shot entirely on location with direct sound recording. It was hailed by Vittorio De Sica as an example for the Italian Neo-Realist School. See also: ‘La femme du boulanger’ directed by Marcel Pagnol (X000449).

Credits: Director, Marcel Pagnol ; writer, Marcel pagnol ; photography, Willy [Faktorovitch], Roger Ledru ; music, Vincent Scotto ; editor, Suzanne de Troeye ; art direction, Marius Brouquier.
Cast: Henri Poupon, Annie Toinon, Orane Demazis, Fernandel, Edouart Delmont, Jean Servais, Andrex, Charles Blavette, Blanche Poupon, Darcelys.

results.title: L'amour D'une Femme = the Love of a Woman
results.brief_description:
Marie, a young doctor, is setting up practice on the Island of Ouessant (off the coast of Brittany). Marie must first overcome the local male population’s built-in misogyny. Gradually, she convinces everyone that she’s as qualified for her job as any man. She shares her time between her work and Ms. Leblanc, a retired schoolteacher, with whom she has become friends. When Andre, an engineeer, arrives on the island, the equilibrium of Marie’s life is upset. This was Jean Gremillon’s last film. One of the least known of the great French directors of the 1930s, Gremillon is possibly the most ‘classic’ in his combination of realism and popular genres. Gremillon’s atmospheric realism, especially his depictions of social milieux (typographers, seamen, the provincial bourgeoisie), echoed his definition that ‘it is a question not of mechanical naturalism, but, rather, of the beauty in achieving the maximum of expression within the maximum of order.’ He also, unusually, offered portraits of remarkably strong women in ‘Le ciel est a vous’ and ‘L’amour d’une femme’, feminist heroines ‘avant la lettre’, struggling equally with work and love.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The Companion to French Cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Gerin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Rene Fallet, Rene Wheeler ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Henri Dutilleux ; editor, Margueritte Renoir.
Cast: Micheline Presle, Massimo Girotti, Gaby Morlay, Julien Carette, Maude Siame.
